http://www.lynwood.ca.us// |footnotes = }} '''Lynwood''' is a city in [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]], [[California]], [[United States of America]]. As of the 2010 census, the city had a total population of 69,772, down from 69,845 at the 2000 census. Lynwood is located near [[South Gate, California|South Gate]] and [[Compton, California|Compton]] in the southern portion of the [[Los Angeles Basin]]. Incorporated in 1921, the city is named for Mrs. Lynn Wood Sessions, wife of a local dairyman, Charles Sessions. The local railroad siding and later [[Pacific Electric Railway]] station were named after the dairy.<ref name="from J. Jack Willard recalls Lynwood">http://openlibrary.org/b/OL5062558M/J._Jack_Willard_recalls_Lynwood</ref>
==Geography== Lynwood is located at {{Coord|33|55|29|N|118|12|7|W|city}} (33.924642, -118.201862).{{GR|1}}
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of 4.8 square miles (12.5 kmÂ²), all land.
==Demographics== ===2010=== The [[2010 United States Census]]<ref>{{USCensus-2010CA}}</ref> reported that Lynwood had a population of 69,772. The [[population density]] was 14,415.7 people per square mile (5,565.9/kmÂ²). The racial makeup of Lynwood was 27,444 (39.3%) [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 7,168 (10.3%) [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 464 (0.7%) [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 457 (0.7%) [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 206 (0.3%) [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 31,652 (45.4%) from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 2,381 (3.4%) from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 60,452 persons (86.6%).
The Census reported that 67,120 people (96.2% of the population) lived in households, 449 (0.6%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 2,203 (3.2%) were institutionalized.
There were 14,680 households, out of which 9,790 (66.7%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 8,303 (56.6%) were [[marriage|opposite-sex married couples]] living together, 3,266 (22.2%) had a female householder with no husband present, 1,569 (10.7%) had a male householder with no wife present. There were 1,281 (8.7%) [[POSSLQ|unmarried opposite-sex partnerships]], and 105 (0.7%) [[same-sex partnerships|same-sex married couples or partnerships]]. 1,064 households (7.2%) were made up of individuals and 328 (2.2%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 4.57. There were 13,138 [[family (U.S. Census)|families]] (89.5% of all households); the average family size was 4.62.
The population was spread out with 22,977 people (32.9%) under the age of 18, 8,705 people (12.5%) aged 18 to 24, 21,245 people (30.4%) aged 25 to 44, 13,075 people (18.7%) aged 45 to 64, and 3,770 people (5.4%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 27.8 years. For every 100 females there were 94.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 91.1 males.
There were 15,277 housing units at an average density of 3,156.4 per square mile (1,218.7/kmÂ²), of which 6,829 (46.5%) were owner-occupied, and 7,851 (53.5%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 1.9%; the rental vacancy rate was 3.7%. 34,023 people (48.8% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 33,097 people (47.4%) lived in rental housing units.
===2000=== As of the [[census]] of [[2000]], there are 69,845 people, 14,395 households, and 12,941 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] is 5,560.3/km² (14,389.2/mi²). There are 14,987 housing units at an average density of 1,193.1/km² (3,087.6/mi²). The racial makeup of the city is 33.62% [[White (U.S. Census)|white]], 13.53% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 1.20% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 0.76% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.39% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 46.14% from other races, and 4.36% from two or more races. 82.33% of the population are [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race.
There are 14,395 households out of which 63.5% have children under the age of 18 living with them, 60.5% are married couples living together, 20.6% have a female householder with no husband present, and 10.1% are non-families. 7.7% of all households are made up of individuals and 2.6% have someone living alone who is 65 years of age or older. The average household size is 4.70 and the average family size is 4.76.
In the city the population is spread out with 38.0% under the age of 18, 13.1% from 18 to 24, 31.2% from 25 to 44, 13.5% from 45 to 64, and 4.2% who are 65 years of age or older. The median age is 24 years. For every 100 females there are 104.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there are 104.2 males.
The median income for a household in the city is $35,888, and the median income for a family is $35,808. Males have a median income of $23,241 versus $19,149 for females. The per capita income for the city is $9,542. 23.5% of the population and 21.0% of families are below the poverty line. Out of the total people living in poverty, 28.3% are under the age of 18 and 14.3% are 65 or older.
As of 2000, speakers of [[Spanish language|Spanish]] as their [[first language]] accounted for 77.43% of residents, while [[English language|English]] was spoken by 22.13%, [[Thai language|Thai]] was spoken by 0.16%, [[Samoan language|Samoan]] was spoken by 0.09%, [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] was spoken by 0.07%, [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] was spoken by 0.07%, [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] by 0.05% of the population.<ref name="MLALanguage">{{cite web |url=http://www.mla.org/map_data_results&state_id=6&county_id=&mode=&zip=&place_id=44574&cty_id=&ll=&a=&ea=&order=r |title=Data Center Results - Lynwood, California] |publisher=[[Modern Language Association]] |accessdate=2009-11-18}}</ref>
Lynwood went through five phases of demographic change in the 20th century. First, a colonial settlement. Second, a farming small town. Third, a mostly working-class white suburb from 1940 to 1970. Fourth, a majority [[African-American]] city between 1970 and 1990, and today, a predominantly [[Latino]] community after a wave of immigration took place.
==Government and infrastructure== Fire protection in Lynwood is provided by the [[Los Angeles County Fire Department]]. The LACFD operates Station #147 at 3161 East Imperial Highway and Station #148 at 4262 Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, both in Lynwood, as a part of Battalion 13.<ref>"[http://fire.lacounty.gov/HometownFireStations/HometownFireStations.asp Hometown Fire Stations]." ''[[Los Angeles County Fire Department]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008.</ref>
The [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]] (LASD) operates the Century Station in Lynwood.<ref>"[http://www.lasd.org/stations/for2/century/index.html Century Station]." [[Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department]]. Retrieved on January 21, 2010.</ref>
The [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]] operates the South Health Center in [[Watts, Los Angeles, California|Watts]], [[Los Angeles]], serving Lynwood.<ref>"[http://publichealth.lacounty.gov/phn/docs/HealthCenter/southla.pdf South Health Center]." [[Los Angeles County Department of Health Services]]. Retrieved on March 18, 2010.</ref>
In the [[California State Legislature|state legislature]] Lynwood is located in the 27th [[California State Senate|Senate]] District, represented by Democrat [[Alan Lowenthal]], and in the 50th [[California State Assembly|Assembly]] District, represented by Democrat [[Ricardo Lara]]. Federally, Lynwood is located in [[California's 39th congressional district]], which has a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index|Cook PVI]] of D +13<ref>{{cite web | title = Will Gerrymandered Districts Stem the Wave of Voter Unrest? | publisher = Campaign Legal Center Blog | url=http://www.clcblog.org/blog_item-85.html | accessdate = 2008-02-10}}</ref> and is represented by Democrat [[Linda SÃ¡nchez]].
On March 20, 2006, former mayor Paul H. Richards II was sentenced to 188 months in federal prison after being convicted in 2005 on numerous corruption charges that centered on his funneling of $6 million in city business - including exorbitant no-bid contracts - to a "consulting company" controlled by him and his family. Richards had served on the City Council from 1986 until he was recalled by voters in 2003; during that time he served seven terms as mayor.<ref>{{cite web | title = FORMER MAYOR OF LYNWOOD SENTENCED TO NEARLY 16 YEARS IN PRISON FOR CONVICTION ON FEDERAL CORRUPTION CHARGES | publisher = Campaign Legal Center Blog | url=http://losangeles.fbi.gov/dojpressrel/pressrel06/la032006usa.htm | accessdate = 2008-07-19 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080407224749/http://losangeles.fbi.gov/dojpressrel/pressrel06/la032006usa.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-04-07}}</ref>
The [[United States Postal Service]] operates the Lynwood Post Office at 11200 Long Beach Boulevard and the East Lynwood Post Office at 11634 Atlantic Avenue.<ref>"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/18010?p=3&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Lynwood Post Office Location - LYNWOOD]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008.</ref><ref>"[http://usps.whitepages.com/service/post_office/57027?p=3&s=CA&service_name=post_office&z=Lynwood Post Office Location - EAST LYNWOOD]." ''[[United States Postal Service]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008.</ref>
== Notable natives / residents of Lynwood == * [["Weird Al" Yankovic]], parody musician;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weirdal.com/faq.htm |title="Weird Al" Yankovic: Frequently Asked Questions|accessdate=2009-01-09}}</ref> named his album ''[[Straight Outta Lynwood]]'' in honor of his hometown * [[Rick Adelman]], NBA coach * [[Steve Smith (American football, born 1979)|Steve Smith]], four-time Pro Bowl wide receiver * [[Venus Williams]], tennis player and former [[List of WTA number 1 ranked players|World no. 1]] and 7 time Grand Slam winner * [[Kevin Costner]], actor<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/bp-excited-kevin-costners-oil-cleanup-machine-purchases/story?id=10916445|title=BP 'Excited' Over Kevin Costner's Oil Cleanup Machine, Purchases 32|accessdate=2010-12-28}}</ref> * [[Jeff Tedford]], college football coach * [[Pat Martin (Broadcaster)]], broadcaster at KMET-FM, Los Angeles, KGB-FM, San Diego, and KRXQ Sacramento * [[Dave Stevens]], artist, illustrator and creator of "[[Rocketeer|The Rocketeer.]]" * [[Julio G]], radio DJ * [[Duke Snider]], Hall of Fame outfielder for the Brooklyn and [[Los Angeles Dodgers]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailynews.com/sports/ci_17499486|title=KEISSER: Snider's regal path to Brooklyn started in Los Angeles - LA Daily News|last=Keisser|first=Bob|date=28 February 2011|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref> * [[Efren Navarro]] Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim infielder *[[Suge Knight]] Founder and CEO of Black Kapital Records and co-founder and former CEO of Death Row Records.
== Education == Most of Lynwood is served by the [[Lynwood Unified School District]].<ref>[http://www.lynwood.k12.ca.us/ Official website], Lynwood Unified School District</ref> High schools include [[Lynwood High School]], [[Marco Antonio Firebaugh High School]] , and [[Vista High School (Lynwood, California)|Vista High School]].
From 1939â1993, Lynwood Adventist Academy (www.lynwoodacademy.com) was located at 11011 Harris Ave. It was taken by eminent domain to make way for the new Lynwood High School campus.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}
===Public libraries=== [[County of Los Angeles Public Library]] operates the Lynwood Library at 11320 Bullis Road.<ref>"[http://www.colapublib.org/libs/lynwood/ Lynwood Library]." ''[[County of Los Angeles Public Library]]''. Retrieved on December 6, 2008.</ref>
